awd_titl_txt: Digitization:  iDigBio: Integrated Digitized Biocollections Phase 2
awd_abstract_narration:
Integrated Digitized Biocollections (idigbio.org) at the University of Florida (UF) and Florida State University (FSU) is the national resource for Advancing Digitization of Biodiversity Collections (ADBC). The ADBC program was developed in response to the need for a sustained effort to digitize, and make available online, the vast amount of information in the nation's biodiversity collections, which may contain up to 1 billion specimens. For biological specimens, information digitized include names of species, localities and dates of collection, digital photographs, sound, video, and 3-D models created from a variety of sources. This community digitization effort is supported by ADBC through Thematic Collections Networks (TCNs), groups of institutions that digitize specimens to address a major research topic such as the relationship between agricultural crops and insects or the impacts of invasive species on natural ecosystems. iDigBio assists in coordinating activities of the TCNs by facilitating development of standards and workflows for digitization of specimens and related information, providing cyberinfrastructure resources to enable long-term preservation of digital data, promoting novel and traditional uses of collections data in research and outreach, and working with the collections community to plan for the long-term sustainability of the national program and the resources that program has produced. The availability of digitized information about specimens greatly enhances the ability to conduct research on biological diversity and to address some of the most fundamental questions in biology. 

In the past five years, the national effort to digitize information in the nation's biodiversity collections has been successfully catalyzed by funding from NSF and advanced by activities of iDigBio. Collaborations with data providers and users have been developed, goals and priorities defined, and best practices related to digitization identified. Cyberinfrastructure resources, including a national search portal, have been provided. These community-driven activities have led to improved digitization practices, increased involvement in digitization and training, and adoption of instruments and informatics tools that improve the efficiency and scalability of digitization and research workflows in all types of biodiversity collections. iDigBio works with staff in more than 450 collections in 270 institutions distributed in all 50 states. Communication among stakeholders to increase access to collections data has been established through workshops, webinars, and the use of social media. iDigBio has sponsored attendance of more than 2,200 participants from 511 institutions to over 65 workshops and symposia that targeted digitization. iDigBio has ingested more than 670 record sets containing 48 million records and 13 million images. All data ingested are indexed so that queries and other types of index-based access are supported. Searches for data can be done through a Web-based graphical interface or through programmatic APIs. Search and analytical tools enable users to mine diverse data such as taxonomy, location, images, traits, and vocalizations. Funding for another five years, will allow iDigBio to continue its successful strategies with an increasing emphasis on data improvement and use in research and outreach. This national resource created by the ADBC program is increasingly recognized as an essential resource for information on biodiversity and digitization. As the scientific and societal benefits of validated collections data are realized, digitization will become a common and sustained practice in natural history collections.

por.por_cntn:
Integrated Digitized Biocollections (iDigBio) at the University of Florida (UF) and Florida State University (FSU) is the national coordinating center for NSF’s Advancing Digitization of Biodiversity Collections (ADBC) Program. ADBC was developed in response to the need for a sustained program to digitize information in U.S, biodiversity collections. Digitization captures and stores digital information from natural history specimens, including text from labels, catalogs, and field books, high-resolution digital images, and 3-D models created from a variety of sources.

Natural history collections provide the best source of biodiversity information on the planet. Digitized specimens enhance data availability and contribute to fundamental biological research and ready-to-analyze data for answering questions about species distribution spanning temporal, spatial, and ecological scales and focused on life history, speciation, dispersal, and extinction. The data also elucidate connections between biodiversity and ecosystem functions that ultimately impact human welfare and predict profound societal and economic consequences of global change.

Digitization is supported through Thematic Collections Networks (TCNs), groups of U.S. institutions that digitize specimen-based data to address major research topics. This national effort is catalyzed by funding from NSF and activities of iDigBio, which was initially launched in 2011 and continued into Phase 2. Facilitating biodiversity research through digitization and data mobilization remains a major focus of iDigBio with an increased emphasis on data use, outreach activities, and sustainability.

Digitization priorities have been defined, best practices have been integrated into workflows, cyberinfrastructure resources including a search portal have been provided, working groups have focused on major challenges, and collaborations with data providers/users have been built. Community-driven activities have led to improved digitization practices, increased involvement in digitization and training, and adoption of informatics tools that improve efficiency and scalability in all types of collections.

iDigBio works with staff in ~1,600 U.S. collections from ~350 institutions, promoting digitization, data access, and use through workshops, webinars, web content, and social media. During Phase 2, iDigBio supported attendance of 11,000 individuals in 270 workshops, webinars, and events representing multiple preparation types. iDigBio has ingested 1,804 recordsets containing more than 138 million records and 53 million associated media records representing ~450 million specimens. All data are indexed for query access. Searches can be done through a Web-based graphical interface or API. Search tools enable users to mine taxonomy, geography, images, and vocalizations.

Broader Impacts: Project awareness has been accomplished through an extensive web and social media presence, digitization courses at UF and FSU, production of online informational videos, outreach at national and international conferences, and workshops and webinars on digitization workflows, georeferencing, Data Carpentry, project management, collections management, citizen science, education & outreach (E&O), and broadening participation. iDigBio co-sponsors with partner institutions the annual Digital Data in Biodiversity Research conference and the Biodiversity Digitization Conference. These conferences have become significant to the worldwide collection community. E&O efforts in Phase 2 have expanded TCN activities through programs that emphasize digitization, biodiversity informatics, and the value of collections data for understanding biodiversity. iDigBio is an official GBIF data hosting center and organizational member. Primarily focused on U.S. collections, iDigBio has developed global partnerships in support of data migration into a globally accessible, well-vetted database that links multiple sources of occurrence, genomic, environmental, and ecological data. We help data providers prepare and map their data to Darwin Core data standards and achieve USGS endorsement for ingestion by GBIF. iDigBio enjoys close relationships with the European Distributed System of Scientific Collections (DiSSCo), an initiative of major significance that unifies natural science collections in Europe and closely aligns in activities with iDigBio, other leading aggregators, and the Atlas of Living Australia (ALA).  

iDigBio’s Digitization, Workforce Development, and Citizen Science domain launched iDigBio’s Digitization Academy in summer 2020 with courses focused on digitization and public participation. Courses are now offered twice a year. iDigBio engages K-20 educators and students with a focus on increasing the use of biodiversity data in the classroom. Lifelong learners have been targeted through close integration of Citizen Science activities, including WeDigBio, which has logged over 120 hours from citizen scientists across the globe and completed more than 62,000 specimen-based transcriptions. iDigBio co-sponsors with TRIO Student Support Services and the UF Office of Academic Support the annual iDigTRIO conference, an event targeted specifically for high school, undergraduate, and graduate students and aimed at exploring career opportunities in biology and paleontology for TRIO program participants -- students that are first generation college, low-income, and/or with disabilities. During the final years of Phase 2, iDigBio was awarded a supplement for its Summer Internship Program, which funded ~30 undergraduate students from accredited institutions for 8-week internships within partnering natural history museums.


Last Modified: 12/22/2023
Modified by: Roy M Nelson

Image
  • Locales of institutions in the ADBC program at the end of Phase 2. Not shown are those in Alaska, Hawaii, and Guam.
    iDigBio
    Creative Commons
    Roy M Nelson
    ADBC Institutions Phase 2

Integrated Digitized Biocollections (iDigBio) at the University of Florida (UF) and Florida State University (FSU) is the national coordinating center for NSFs Advancing Digitization of Biodiversity Collections (ADBC) Program. ADBC was developed in response to the need for a sustained program to digitize information in U.S, biodiversity collections. Digitized specimens enhance data availability and contribute to fundamental biological research and ready-to-analyze data for answering questions about species distribution spanning temporal, spatial, and ecological scales and focused on life history, speciation, dispersal, and extinction. The data also elucidate connections between biodiversity and ecosystem functions that ultimately impact human welfare and predict profound societal and economic consequences of global change.




Digitization is supported through Thematic Collections Networks (TCNs), groups of U.S. institutions that digitize specimen-based data to address major research topics. iDigBios Digitization, Workforce Development, and Citizen Science domain launched iDigBios Digitization Academy in summer 2020 with courses focused on digitization and public participation.
